commit_message:
Use testtools as test base class.

On the path to testr migration, we need to replace the unittest base classes
with testtools.
Replace tearDown with addCleanup, addCleanup is more resilient than tearDown.
The fixtures library has excellent support for managing and cleaning
tempfiles. Use it.
Replace skip_ with testtools.skipTest

Part of blueprint grizzly-testtools.

Change-Id: I45e11bbb1ff9b31f3278d3b016737dcb7850cd98

commit_message:
Start adding reusable test fixtures.

Now that nova is using fixtures, we have grown some that can be used across
projects. The mox/stubout fixture is a great example of this - and also can
be used in the oslo tests themselves.

Change-Id: Ia78019317a6772c5c66a875c948854248383f9ea

(2 inline comments)

Hi,
Some minor nits.
Why not address the other agents too?
Thanks
Gary"}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2013-01-28 07:30:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Quantum distributions do not necessarily use the upstream config files. Why prevent them from combining all the config files into one, or organizing them in whatever way makes most sense for that distribution?"}, {'account_id': 6659, 'date': '2013-01-28 07:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 6659, 'date': '2013-01-28 07:30:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (3 inline comments)

RE: Other agents... I'd be glad to address the other agents, however, I don't know what plugin config files to use to test a working case (couldn't find them in the code), and am not sure how to setup to run them (to test working case). Can someone advise?"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-01-28 07:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/19649/2/check/gate-quantum-docs/3030 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/19649/2/check/gate-quantum-pep8/3650 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/19649/2/check/gate-quantum-python26/3421 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/19649/2/check/gate-quantum-python27/3421 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/19649/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/1452 : SUCCESS (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/19649/2/check/gate-devstack-vm-quantum/4006 : SUCCESS (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-01-28 07:30:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

A few thoughts ...


IMHO, we should never issue warnings based on whether configuration *files* were specified ... we should warn about configuration *values* not being acceptable

Configuration values can be specified via the command line, files loaded by --config-file, files loaded by --config-dir and the defaults specified in the code ... why require that a certain number of --config-file arguments were specified when it's the resultant configuration values we care about?


If you want the core_plugin option to be a required option, just mark it as required:

      cfg.StrOpt('core_plugin', required=True),


If you want to check whether an option value is None, do:

  if CONF.core_plugin is None:

this:

  if CONF.get('core_plugin', None) is None:

only makes since if the core_plugin option may not be registered ... and that should never happen."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-01-28 07:30:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Also, Bob's point that it should be valid for a user to just use a single file is perfectly correct IMO"}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2013-01-28 07:30:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I'd like some input from other reviewers on whether the in-tree config file layout is the expected/required layout at deployment, or is simply the organization used for development. Since the configuration files to be loaded were made completely controllable from the command line, I've been assuming these command line options could be used as seen fit for deployment.

I'd like to set the right precedent here. If distributions have the freedom to reorganise the configuration file(s), then we shouldn't even log warnings based on deviations from the development layout. Logging info about the config files used would be OK though."}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2013-01-28 07:30:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Warning if the core plugin isn't specified is fine, but I do not think services should require using multiple configuration files. We organize it that way in the source code tree so that changes to different plugins' configuration items don't effect the same files, but distributions might organize their configuration files differently, such as all on one file."}, {'account_id': 6659, 'date': '2013-01-28 07:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Just to elaborate the intention is to just log a message, so that the user is aware that they may have missed a config file. It is not intending to "require" plugins. Should this be an "info" logging for the plugin configs?'}, {'account_id': 6659, 'date': '2013-01-28 07:30:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Uploaded a second patch set, which looks for the core_plugin attribute to tell if core config was missing, and to look to see if a plugin config file was specified.  I couldn't find a attribute(s) to check to tell if the plugin config was provided, as it appears that defaults are used (e.g. cfg.CONF.OVS.integration_bridge or cfg.CONF.DATABASE.sql_connection).

So, taking the simple approach of just seeing if only one file is specified and if it is one that provides the core config, then *possibly* the plugin config is missing.

Granted, the user could have one config file with all the config, but I don't know how we tell if they are missing config information, as was identified in the bug (a core config was provided, but not a plugin config)."}, {'account_id': 6659, 'date': '2013-01-28 07:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6659, 'date': '2013-01-28 07:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

So one part of the change can be the logging of attributes specified from the set of config files used.

Should we, as part of the validation process, check that some mandatory core attributes are set?

If so, would just checking core_plugin, be adequate for checking core attributes?

If true, I see these possibilities:
A) check that for each agent at startup and throw an exception
B) make core_plugin a "required" attribute
C) other?

BTW: I see with B that there are many UTs that I think are not expecting this to be set.

For plugin based attributes, are there any we should check?
If so, how do we check them (as I see defaults applied), or should we remove the defaults, so that we can check them to see if they are set?
Should these "validations" be left as a future enhancement, per plugin (versus this bugfix)?'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-01-28 07:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Build succeeded.

Thanks Mark, however, Jenkins failed. The unit tests passed in my area, so I am re-running the unit tests and trying to understand what happened.'}, {'account_id': 6659, 'date': '2013-01-28 07:30:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Hitting two issues with patch set #4...

1) Jenkins fails the test_debug_commands.py and test_dhcp_agent.py, but it works with my local repo, which is based on gerrit/master (f45a015) latest and my changes. The failures are that these two directly call ConfigOpts._check_required_opts() and no test config file is specified. I can add in the config file, but without getting the same test results I cannot verify (other than committing).

2) The test_dhcp_agent.py test_dhcp_agent_main() ends up calling production code dhcp_agent.main() and that does a registration of the core_plugin config option (via import of quantum.agent.common.config, which imports quantum.common.config, which has core_plugin as required now). Would the DHCP agent typically load a config file that has core_plugin set? I'm concerned about whether or not the core_plugin is indeed 'required' by everyone.

Any guidance?"}, {'account_id': 6659, 'date': '2013-01-28 07:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 6659, 'date': '2013-01-28 07:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

Please see questions in comment.'}, {'account_id': 6659, 'date': '2013-01-28 07:30:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

Reply to inline comment. Open question as to why we don't have logging constants defined in quantum common log module."}, {'account_id': 6659, 'date': '2013-01-28 07:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Proposal for patch #5. Please comment:

A) log configuration option settings for each of the 4 plugin agents @ startup
B) Check core_plugin setting in the 4 plugin agents ~ patch 3 (diff wording)

Can't make core_plugin a mandatory config option, because there are some agents (at least DHCP), which define the option, but do not require it. To support patch 4, we'd have to either override the "required" attribute for the core_plugin config option in places or include a dummy value to prevent failure. Both seem like poor solutions, IMHO.

I'll post the patch in an hour or so, unless I hear comments indicating a different direction.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-01-28 07:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me

class TestCoreConfigOptions(unittest.TestCase):

Something like that ...
Thanks
Gary"}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-01-28 07:30:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

'}, {'created': '2013-01-28 07:30:13.000000000', 'message': 'Make core_plugin mandatory & show cfg opts loaded.

For each of the quantum plugin agents, show the configuration

'}, {'created': '2013-01-28 07:30:13.000000000', 'message': 'Log warn if core cfg missing. Show attrs loaded.

Fix provides two changes to the quantum plugin agents. First,
the current set of attributes that have been configured, is
logged (similar to what the quantum server does).

Second, a check is made to see if the core_plugin attribute
exists. This is a mandatory attribute, which does not have a
default. If not found, an exception will be thrown and a log
entry generated:

stack@ubuntu:~/quantum$ bin/quantum-openvswitch-agent
   --config-file etc/quantum/plugins/openvswitch/ovs_quantum_plugin.ini
2013-01-18 14:18:18.801 1245 CRITICAL quantum [-] Quantum core_plugin
    not configured!

Test the four plugin agents (linuxbridge, nec, openvswitch,
and ryu). The quantum server already checks this attribute and
throws the same exception.

Note: Since this test is needed by every plugin, it was put
in a new module at quantum/agent/common/. In the future, if
additional tests are desired for core attributes or there are
some shared plugin attributes to validate, this module could
be used (and the function could be changed to a class, if it
makes sense).

Agents with specific attribute validation can perform their
validation and then call the shared core attribute validation.

bug 1059923
Change-Id: I813f0c2a3d0ec01be74a34e56ab085979197a16a
'}, {'created': '2013-01-28 07:30:13.000000000', 'message': 'Log warn if quantum core and/or plugin config missing.

bug 1059923

Addresses quantum server, and linuxbridge, ovs, ryu, and nec
plugin agents generating a warnign log message, when config files
are missing. Check to see if core_plugin attribute exists to tell if
the core config file is there. Check # config files to see if a plugin
config is there. For server, tested these cases:

no conf specifed (uses /etc/quantum/quantum.conf) -> warn plugin cfg missing
core conf specified -------------------------------> warn plugin cfg missing
core + plugin conf specified ----------------------> no warning
plugin conf specified -----------------------------> no warning

For last test case, (existing) CRITICAL msg will be displayed by the server.

For plugins, tested these cases:

no conf specifed (uses /etc/quantum/quantum.conf) -> warn plugin cfg missing
core conf specified -------------------------------> warn plugin cfg missing
core + plugin conf specified ----------------------> no warning
plugin conf specified -----------------------------> warn core config missing

Change-Id: I813f0c2a3d0ec01be74a34e56ab085979197a16a
'}, {'created': '2013-01-28 07:30:13.000000000', 'message': 'Log warning, if < 2 config files provided at startup

For quantum server and openvswitch plugin agent, if less than two config
files are provided (typically, /etc/openstack/quantum  is provided, if none
are selected), we will print a warning, as both a general and plugin specific
settings should be provided at startup. Ref:

http://docs.openstack.org/trunk/openstack-network/admin/content/quantum_server.html

Ran unit tests and manually invoked these with 0, 1, and 2 arguments for
config_file. Warning logged, when less than two specified.

Note, this check could be added to the linuxbridge, NEC, and RYU plugin
agents (if that makes sense). However, to do so, need to know the name of
the second configuration file and how to start up the agents.

Change-Id: I813f0c2a3d0ec01be74a34e56ab085979197a16a
Fixes: bug 1059923
'}]
commit_message:
Reqd. core_plugin for plugin agents & show cfg opts loaded.

For the linuxbridge, openvswitch, nec, and ryu plugin agents,
require the core_plugin configuration option, and throw an
exception, if not present. Note: cannot make this a required
option for all agents, as there are agent that include the
core config options, but do not require core_plugin.

In addition, log (as debug) the configuration options that
have been loaded at start-up for these four agents. This will
help with diagnosing start-up issues related to the
configuraiton settings (or lack of).

Tested that exception thrown, when missing core_plugin
value in config file(s) included, for these four agents.

bug 1059923
Change-Id: I813f0c2a3d0ec01be74a34e56ab085979197a16a

[{'created': '2012-12-12 07:38:05.000000000', 'message': 'handle kern.log rotation in swift-drive-audit

Supports kern.log rotation in order to avoid loss of significant information.

I thought this was a good idea and the previous one expired.

Except I just shell out to tac(1) instead of reversing the file myself.
This script's pretty linux-specific anyway, and tac is a core util.

commit_message:
handle kern.log rotation in swift-drive-audit

Supports kern.log rotation in order to avoid loss of significant information.

I thought this was a good idea and the previous one expired.

Except I just shell out to tac(1) instead of reversing the file myself.
This script's pretty linux-specific anyway, and tac is a core util.

Also fix a bug where "logger" is referenced but doesn't exist in get_errors.

Change-Id: I92a119e270fd4df8356397f6d507bb76aa5145a5

commit_message:
Missing session argument to task_log_* in sqlalchemy/api.py

The following functions db/api.py need to have the session
argument removed so that they are compatible with
sqlalchemy/api.py
(Otherwise they fail with too many arguments being passed)

task_log_get()
task_log_get_all()
task_log_begin_task()
task_log_end_task()

Also in sqlalchemy/api.py task_log_get() and
task_log_get_all() need to pass context to _task_log_get_query()

Change-Id: I38dd72f728167659e10a8dc6cef1b0652597e0b3

[{'created': '2013-01-27 17:36:54.000000000', 'message': 'Multi-tenancy isolation with aggregates

A new scheduler filter that allows the creation of instances from
specific tenants in selected aggregates.
With this filter is possible to isolate tenants in a specific set
of compute nodes (aggregates).

If a host is in an aggregate that has the metadata key
"filter_tenant_id" it can only create instances from that tenant(s).
A host can be in different aggregates.
If a host doesn't belong to an aggregate with the metadata key
"filter_tenant_id" it can create instances from all tenants.

Implements: blueprint multi-tenancy-aggregates
DocImpact

Change-Id: I6ff2f0e1a110aed706015574d3dc9125f96a1871
'}]
commit_message:
Multi-tenancy isolation with aggregates

A new scheduler filter that allows the creation of instances from
specific tenants in selected aggregates.
With this filter is possible to isolate tenants in a specific set
of compute nodes (aggregates).

If a host is in an aggregate that has the metadata key
"filter_tenant_id" it can only create instances from that tenant(s).
A host can be in different aggregates.
If a host doesn't belong to an aggregate with the metadata key
"filter_tenant_id" it can create instances from all tenants.

Implements: blueprint multi-tenancy-aggregates
DocImpact

Change-Id: I6ff2f0e1a110aed706015574d3dc9125f96a1871

Change params for windows vm boot

commit_message:
OVS: update status according to admin_state_up

Fixes bug 1099099

In addition to this the code does the following:
1. validates if the port exists on the OVS when a port update event takes
   place
2. when a port is created the initial state is set as 'DOWN'. this is
   later updated by the agent when it is detected as up

Change-Id: I917d4b5aa8df7395fcaa841d77083546478739d2

commit_message:
Add Wordpress template with ConfigSet

ConfigSet are not yet implemented in heat.
Bug is reported on launchpad : bug 1101717

This template should install Wordpress when ConfigSet will work.

Change-Id: Iff9ef35ad85df6c11031862a8ba5de57a9d37714

commit_message:
Fixes pre tenant quota driver with wrong path

Fixes Bug #1103859

Currently in document, the pre tenant quota driver was
'quantum.extensions._quotav2_driver.DbQuotaDriver'.
It should be 'quantum.db.quota_db.DbQuotaDriver'.

Change-Id: Ieda3f9e8815fb28d161c7ab9dcb739bca6b16485

commit_message:
Bring Glance API in HA on API Node

* Clean Keystone Part
* Create a VIP for API Cluster
* Explain how to bring Glance API in HA
* Create a pacemaker group for resources

commit_message:
fix delay_auth_decision parameter

fixes bug 1092564

as noted in the bug, delay_auth_decision is a int, not a bool

this change uses the value from Folsom.

Change-Id: I6a35cd055c99c2233a981009b247cafce4ebbe81

commit_message:
Document tools/flakes is from commons

When copying tools around it may not be clear that they came from
openstack-common.  So add a note at top of code. Had to say from
openstack-common since cannot say from oslo-incubator since word oslo is
replaced when copied.

Change-Id: I7514c88d448f13cb7b11ed1ea81a035c6a201bae

"}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2013-01-18 10:03:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

A few general points about this.
You really shouldn't be hiding all OSError exceptions.
What if EIO was silently swallowed for example?

also calling rmdir from a function called unlink_....()
is too confusing. I'd suggest renaming to a more abstract
remove_...().

Also the tests for file existence seem redundant and racy.
Following the "it's better to ask forgiveness than persmission" idiom, to avoid logic duplication and TOCTOU races, I'd just handle the exception from unlink.

BTW if you really just care about swallowing ENOENTs
from unlink, then I suggest you use instead utils.delete_if_exists()

Also it seems you may want to shutil.rmtree() rather than rmdir? but I've haven't looked deeply enough to determine that'}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2013-01-18 17:16:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> You really shouldn't be hiding all OSError exceptions.

This is called from places that IMHO need to continue no-matter-what, hence the hiding of OSErrors.

> also calling rmdir from a function called unlink_....() is too confusing. I'd suggest renaming to a more abstract remove_...().

Fair 'nuf. I can rename this function.

> Also it seems you may want to shutil.rmtree() rather than rmdir?

I was hesitant to rmtree(), but there are two places where this is probably needed. 

Rewrite coming shortly..."}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2013-01-18 17:29:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2013-01-18 17:55:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Change-Id: Ie36f59dce34a6c67765770c5f968c003003acc88
'}, {'created': '2013-01-22 03:31:24.000000000', 'message': 'Baremetal/utils should not log certain exceptions

unlink_without_raise was logging exceptions when it failed to unlink a
file, which is confusing since it is often called on non-existing files.

create_link_without_raise was also logging exceptions when it failed
to create a symlink.

This patch corrects this behaviour; both functions now explicitly check
for the type of error they expect, and then suppress that. If another
type of OSError is encountered, a warning is logged. This patch also
adds unit tests for both functions.

fixes bug 1097931.

Change-Id: Ie36f59dce34a6c67765770c5f968c003003acc88
'}]
commit_message:
Baremetal/utils should not log certain exceptions

unlink_without_raise was logging exceptions when it failed to unlink a
file, which is confusing since it is often called on non-existing files.

create_link_without_raise was also logging exceptions when it failed
to create a symlink.

This patch corrects this behaviour; both functions now explicitly check
for the type of error they expect, and then suppress that. If another
type of OSError is encountered, a warning is logged. This patch also
adds unit tests for both functions.

fixes bug 1097931.

Change-Id: Ie36f59dce34a6c67765770c5f968c003003acc88

[{'created': '2013-01-18 17:52:48.000000000', 'message': "PXE driver should rmtree directories it created

Baremetal PXE driver was failing to delete the per-instance tftpboot and
image directories which it created when the instance was deleted. This
happened partly because of dangling files within the directory, and
partly because 'unlink' does not remove directories and the error was
squelched.

Now, when destroy()ing an instance, PXE driver will call shutil.rmtree()
on the per-instance directories which it created.

Fixes bug 1101048.

Change-Id: I682d0264288add488ea23e5d5200357b7be52dd9
"}, {'created': '2013-01-22 03:01:43.000000000', 'message': "PXE driver should rmtree directories it created

Baremetal PXE driver was failing to delete the per-instance tftpboot and
image directories which it created when the instance was deleted. This
happened partly because of dangling files within the directory, and
partly because 'unlink' does not remove directories and the error was
squelched.

Now, when destroy()ing an instance, PXE driver will call shutil.rmtree()
on the per-instance directories which it created.

Fixes bug 1101048.

Change-Id: I682d0264288add488ea23e5d5200357b7be52dd9
"}]
commit_message:
PXE driver should rmtree directories it created

Baremetal PXE driver was failing to delete the per-instance tftpboot and
image directories which it created when the instance was deleted. This
happened partly because of dangling files within the directory, and
partly because 'unlink' does not remove directories and the error was
squelched.

Now, when destroy()ing an instance, PXE driver will call shutil.rmtree()
on the per-instance directories which it created.

Fixes bug 1101048.

Change-Id: I682d0264288add488ea23e5d5200357b7be52dd9

commit_message:
ensure failure to inject user files results in startup error

This was the case in Essex but was inadvertantly changed in:
folsom-2-95-g0d166ca.

* nova/virt/disk/api.py: Refactor to allow specifying
mandatory injection items, that result in an exception
on failure to inject.
* nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py: Specify that user 'files'
are mandatory items and thus result in VM startup failure
unless injected successfully.
* nova/tests/test_virt_disk.py: A new test for the
separate warning and error cases.

Fixes bug: 1095744
Change-Id: Idab5c4294c1cb52098ce44a7aae957a44fb2674f

commit_message:
Fixes task_log_get and task_log_get_all signatures

Fixes signatures for the above methods in nova/db/api.py
based on the recent TaskLog refactor on sqlalchemy/api.py.
Also adds unit tests for TaskLog.

Fixes Bug 1102652.

Change-Id: Id7ce74b8941d9eb6a50dfbfaa62e0fe05dd467c2

commit_message:
Add system_metadata to db.instance_get_active_by_window_joined

Without this compute/utils/notify_usage_exists() throws an
exception when looking for system_metadata in the instance data

Change-Id: I3606aa18b1aa69f98de820840c080f848af56157

commit_message:
Introduce a new binary, nova-periodic

This change allows you to run periodic tasks of nova-compute that
are marked as being capable of running externally in a separate
process. This is at the request of Yahoo!, who see latency problems
with periodic tasks on heavily loaded compute nodes.

DocImpact.

Change-Id: I743af63d25d74b203b6430b375e4ee8599da2104

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-25 14:03:00.000000000', 'message': "Count revs for revno rather than use git-describe

We currently use 'git describe --always' to figure out the number of
commits there have been leading up to the HEAD commit.

However, if there are no tags in the repo, git-describe just returns
the sha hash of HEAD and we fail.

Use 'git rev-list HEAD | wc -l' instead so we're always #winning.

Change-Id: I345e0ee32189504276b3dfd3367057ce1d4a2b06
"}, {'created': '2013-01-25 17:15:14.000000000', 'message': "Count revs for revno rather than use git-describe

Use 'git rev-list HEAD | wc -l' instead so we're always #winning.

Change-Id: I345e0ee32189504276b3dfd3367057ce1d4a2b06
"}, {'created': '2013-01-25 17:25:25.000000000', 'message': "setup: count revs for revno if there are no tags

We currently use 'git describe --always' to figure out the number of
commits there have been leading up to the HEAD commit.

However, if there are no tags in the repo, git-describe just returns
the sha hash of HEAD and we fail.

In that case, use 'git rev-list HEAD | wc -l' so we can be  #winning.

Change-Id: I345e0ee32189504276b3dfd3367057ce1d4a2b06

commit_message:
setup: count revs for revno if there are no tags

We currently use 'git describe --always' to figure out the number of
commits there have been leading up to the HEAD commit.

However, if there are no tags in the repo, git-describe just returns
the sha hash of HEAD and we fail.

In that case, use 'git rev-list HEAD | wc -l' so we can be  #winning.

Change-Id: I345e0ee32189504276b3dfd3367057ce1d4a2b06

(12 inline comments)

I think that is starting to look really good.

Minor thing, I guess nova/tests/image/store/__init__.py got left behind and needs deleting.

My main concern is around how to maintain the code that has been cut and pasted from glance and swift.

Maybe a good compromise is to create a script that can generate the XenAPI plugins from the glance and swift code, so it will be easier to update it? Maybe make the script run as part of the RPM build process?"}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2013-01-11 21:35:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: (2 inline comments)

Couple responses inline.

I agree with everything else. It does concern me how we will maintain the plugin code, I'll do some brainstorming to come up with a good solution...as it stands right now I know it is a little bit different than what is in glance so I'll figure that out as well."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-01-19 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-01-19 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 5387, 'date': '2013-01-21 20:01:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Restored'}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2013-01-21 21:40:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

With regards to swift and swiftclient.py

I'm not sure having the swift file being as close to copy and paste is a good idea. It seems like it would get even harder to maintain if the interface for the file or a config option changed and we were relying on duplicating the updates to work.

As for swiftclient.py, that originated from a Citrix patch for incremental images. The code that references no longer exists in swift but it is very similar to code found in python-swiftclient. My concerns about generating this code revolves around it not being much easier to maintain since our method of copying this code would require some translation and a breaking change my not be discovered right away since it would likely need a functional test that is hitting an endpoint that uses Xen and these settings.

What I am thinking is making swiftclient.py as minimal as possible and leaving the swift file how it is. Let me know what you think. Ideally in the future we can find a way to install python-swiftclient on dom0 and have a single home for image data transfer logic."}, {'account_id': 2537, 'date': '2013-01-21 22:10:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

I have a couple of comments John:-

1. Having a script at RPM/DEB build process would mean that we are relying on the build process to keep our client updated. (How often would you recommend updating dom0?, considering Glance has a flexible architecture with some possible fundamental changes to come) We would still need to be aware of when and what changes are being made. Seems to me that we will have to do similar things at cost of a lot of changes.

2. Agreeing to what Alex has mentioned here, we have tried to fiddle around trying to get python-swiftclient working on dom0 and found ourselves in a hard place. To us the proposed patch seems to be giving a decent trade-off on different fronts- performance, maintaining code and avoiding dependency mess in dom0.

Please let me know your thoughts.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2013-01-22 09:37:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: No score

I am willing to accept this may be the best we can do right now, I just want to be sure that is true.

I worry about any cut and paste code, particularly when it comes to security fixes.

With the RPM build. I was thinking maybe not include the copied source code in the nova tree, and get the build to pull the file(s) into the RPM, so every time you wish to deploy you get the latest code, but there is no need to keep patching nova everytime the swift client changes. I agree this could end up being very fragile and no better, just wondered if it would be easy.

Can I help with the issues you had getting python-swiftclient working in Dom0? Feel free to email the openstack-dev list. According to the docs, python 2.6 and simplejson should be enough to make it work. This patch already requires python 2.6 being added into Dom0.

I also assumed, if we use the full swift client, there is no longer any need to use the segmentation code from glance, because you could use the code built into the swift client (http://docs.openstack.org/developer/swift/overview_large_objects.html). Although it is really not clear to me why glance doesn't use the segmentation code in the swift client itself. 

I assumed the Citrix code was meant to be proof of concept code, but you would have to check with Bob.

Maybe come along to the XenAPI IRC meeting on Wednesday and discuss it with the people there. Bit easier than comment ping pong."}, {'account_id': 2537, 'date': '2013-01-22 16:10:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Sure and agreed! Lets discuss the pain points of getting python-swiftclient on dom0 offline.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2013-01-24 16:57:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

python-swiftclient and python-keystoneclient seem to install OK into Dom0. I have tried to document how I did that here:
http://wiki.openstack.org/XenServer/PostInstall#Install_Python_2.6_in_Dom0

I hope that helps. Let me know if there are any other issues or queries.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2013-01-25 16:49:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

I guess we are abandoning this one, and replacing with the new one?'}, {'account_id': 2537, 'date': '2013-01-25 17:01:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Yes, we should abandon this."}, {'account_id': 5387, 'date': '2013-01-25 21:47:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Abandoned'}]

xenapi: Direct upload of images to swift

Added support for nova to upload images directly to object store
instead of uploading through glance when using Xen.

Implements bp nova-direct-image-upload
DocImpact

commit_message:
Added LVM configuration to cinder install

Added instructions to add volume_list filter to /etc/lvm/lvm.conf to prevent volumes from entering "Error_Deleting" as specified in bug #1090595. Without the volume filter, LVM will activate logical volumes created in virtual machines, which can can cinder volumes from being deleted.

Change-Id: I40d12bd1772acc2a2b0e6efab36ce3be4c4f28d6

[{'created': '2013-01-23 22:38:15.000000000', 'message': "Avoid db lookup in info_from_instance().

The method info_from_instance() in nova.notifications was doing a db
lookup for the system_metadata for an instance.  This patch updates that
code to get that data from the instance that's passed in instead.  The
rest of the patch are related changes to make that happen.

metadata_to_dict() was needed here.  It lived in nova.compute.utils.
nova.compute.utils already imported nova.notifications, so using it from
there would have created a circular import.  Move the method to
nova.utils instead and update the tree to use it from its new location.

I also noticed that the xen driver had a copy of metdata_to_dict().
This patch removes it and uses the common implementation in nova.utils.

'system_metadata' was added to _extra_keys of the Instance db model so
that it would show up in a serialized instance.  Tests failed without it
as the result of getting instances via the conductor API did not include
system_metadata.  Now it's there.

Part of bp no-db-compute.

Change-Id: I451355fb26ae29f13b71438f7896c448b59f97b0

commit_message:
Avoid db lookup in info_from_instance().

The method info_from_instance() in nova.notifications was doing a db
lookup for the system_metadata for an instance.  This patch updates that
code to get that data from the instance that's passed in instead.  The
rest of the patch are related changes to make that happen.

metadata_to_dict() was needed here.  It lived in nova.compute.utils.
nova.compute.utils already imported nova.notifications, so using it from
there would have created a circular import.  Move the method to
nova.utils instead and update the tree to use it from its new location.

I also noticed that the xen driver had a copy of metdata_to_dict().
This patch removes it and uses the common implementation in nova.utils.

'system_metadata' was added to _extra_keys of the Instance db model so
that it would show up in a serialized instance.  Tests failed without it
as the result of getting instances via the conductor API did not include
system_metadata.  Now it's there.

Part of bp no-db-compute.

Change-Id: I451355fb26ae29f13b71438f7896c448b59f97b0

commit_message:
rename tenant to project in sql

Change is motivated by the need to do an incremental conversion from using
tenant to using project as the name.  The database is isolated from the API
and can be modified without breaking integrations.  ADditional work wil be required
to get the API to meet the V3 spec without breaking the V2 spec

Change-Id: I7cf7695354071f0ea6252be4730ceec3af0a2f35

subject: Credentials Configuration changes
messages:
[{'account_id': 7, 'date': '2013-01-21 22:31:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'm already a bit annoyed that https://review.openstack.org/#/c/20081 went through with such little discussion.

The problem that exists right now is that after the above change, there is no concept of an Keystone admin user that is different from a non-administrative Keystone user. So, it is now not possible to test the Keystone API with a non-Keystone-admin user. :(

We must remember that the Compute API is NOT the only API in OpenStack, and that an admin in Keystone does not necessarily mean that user is an admin in Nova or Quantum or Glance.

Each API has different concepts of what "admin" is, and so if we throw away all non-compute admin users in the configuration, we are not able to fully test the authorization scenarios.

What I believe is a better solution is the following:

* Only store the credentials for a user that has admin rights in Keystone
* In the [compute] configuration section, have a value for non_admin_role and admin_role (defaulting to devstack's corresponding Member and Admin role names)
* Have the Keystone admin user create users in the base compute test class that represent the roles that are used in the compute scenarios. For instance, create users that are non-admin, that are admin, that are network admin, etc
* Repeat for each OpenStack API.

Finally, the Fuzz clients were a prototype meant to show how you can use encapsulation instead of inheritance to handle the creation of fixtures and resources instead of the existing mess of multiple inheritance in the compute tests.'}, {'account_id': 5196, 'date': '2013-01-21 22:32:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

Nice work, this a good clean-up.

But, I think that you should split this up into separate commits. You're doing at least 2 different things here, the whitebox clean-up and the move to credentials in identity. (You might be able to split it up more too)

Also, there is a typo in the commit message."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-01-21 22:47:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed.  For information on how to proceed, see http://wiki.openstack.org/GerritJenkinsGithub#Test_Failures

- http://logs.openstack.org/20182/1/check/gate-tempest-pep8/1693 : FAILURE
- http://logs.openstack.org/20182/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/162 : FAILURE
- http://logs.openstack.org/20182/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres/917 : FAILURE (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/20182/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/1986 : FAILURE
"}, {'account_id': 5196, 'date': '2013-01-21 22:51:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I also agree with Jay's points about the different credentials, but I was saving that discussion for after the patches were split up so we could discuss them separately from the fuzz classes. This is why I went I wrote those WIP patches to split up credential options (which wasn't the right way to do it but was along the same path) 

Also it should be noted that before https://review.openstack.org/#/c/20081 that the separate config options we had for credentials in different project APIs were unused, nova, cinder, and quantum were just using compute credentials for everything."}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-01-22 07:05:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@jaypipes:
"The problem that exists right now is that after the above change, there is no concept of an Keystone admin user that is different from a non-administrative Keystone user."

Now, we have two client classes for keystone one to  Token the Identity. Do we need any another one ?

I just renamed the admin to identity because it was used with users without administrative privileges, and it was confusing.

tempest/tests/identity/base.py:
os = clients.NonAdminManager(interface=cls._interface)
cls.non_admin_client = os.identity_client

Please verify again am I did anything else than rename. I did not wanted to do anything else.

"We must remember that the Compute API is NOT the only API in OpenStack, and that an admin in Keystone does not necessarily mean that user is an admin in Nova or Quantum or Glance."

I started the refactoring in order to do more role based testing, at the first place!

I agree with the on fly user creation concept even by a factory.

I wanted to remove the alt_userneme too, but not everyone liked this idea.
We should not forget the tempest, partially need to work without admin credentials definition against production systems.
We should do it just for the users which are not replaceable by the username or alt_username.

Since now everything is working with a single admin credentials, it is doable in a future commit.
We already does on the fly user creation, even in setUpClass-es. I will check is it doable in a nicer way.

I just removed some really not utilized *Fuzz* code, but
we need to discuss removing the other *Fuzz* classes or replacing the existing ones with it and do a refactoring, because now it is unnecessary duplicated concept.

I want to fix ssh test. An I want to use key based authentication primary, but I need a concept, which allows me to generate keypair once per user and delete it when it is not needed anymore.

Other resources has closer connection to tenants than to the users.

Anyway, I will split this commit, and I'll vote with -1 after jenkins says +1, until your feedback.'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-01-23 22:40:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-01-23 22:44:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Waiting for jaypipes response."}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-01-23 23:06:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-01-23 23:52:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

OK, I am cool with these changes now, after discussions with Attila and others.'}, {'account_id': 5196, 'date': '2013-01-24 16:42:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Attila the credentials look good to me. 

But, I have one little nit, I think that you should break out the whitebox configuration changes into another patch. Since they aren't really related to moving credentials into identity."}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-01-24 18:10:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

@Matthew:

Is it ok for you if I just change the commit message ?

I do not see, why I had to create another patch for that relative small change.'}, {'account_id': 5196, 'date': '2013-01-24 20:45:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

I'm just trying to get tempest committers in the habit of splitting up changes more. It would probably be ok if it got merged like this. But, trying to make Tempest more mature in the future we should really only try to include one feature change per commit regardless of how small the unrelated changes are.

See:

http://wiki.openstack.org/GitCommitMessages#Structural_split_of_changes"}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-01-25 10:44:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-01-25 11:54:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Works for me

commit_message:
Credentials Configuration changes

* Credentials are moved to the identity section
* If the compute admin user defined in the compute-admin section it takes precedence
* The region just defined in the identity section

Change-Id: I1241116ce9312c90656a78235a4a91dd31460761

commit_message:
clean up api_samples documentation

the documentation for API samples was very misleading,
and hard to point people at what to do to add new samples.
Bring this more in line with reality.

Change-Id: I52da343d317cc77e5df30815f3f3721c2634585b

This squelches a deprecation warning during installation.

We're already using extend_existing in other places, so I don't
think this causes any new version compatibility issues.

Fixes bug 925609.  (Already marked fixed, but this hits more cases.)

Change-Id: Ia166e9184ed3e13753c5669a1006a3711738319a

commit_message:
Change useexisting to extend_existing to fix deprecation warnings.

This squelches a deprecation warning during installation.

We're already using extend_existing in other places, so I don't
think this causes any new version compatibility issues.

Fixes bug 925609.  (Already marked fixed, but this hits more cases.)

Includes some merges with a whitespace-cleanup fix.

Change-Id: Ia166e9184ed3e13753c5669a1006a3711738319a

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-25 15:58:30.000000000', 'message': "Fix InvalidContentType can't be raised because of error in constructor

InvalidContentType exception class is defined two times:
in quantum.openstack.common.exception and quantum.common.exceptions
with two different signatures.
A lot of code like wsgi.Serializer.serialize() imports one of them but
attempts to use it with the signature of another one, which ends with
TypeError exception.

This change fixes the bug by removing the second definition of
InvalidContentType class and leaving only one which works correctly
with all code.

Change-Id: I5d932d75ad184a0a6c6419190f2940bd47b7504e
Fixes: bug #1104090

commit_message:
Fix InvalidContentType can't be raised because of error in constructor

InvalidContentType exception class is defined two times:
in quantum.openstack.common.exception and quantum.common.exceptions
with two different signatures.
A lot of code like wsgi.Serializer.serialize() imports one of them but
attempts to use it with the signature of another one, which ends with
TypeError exception.

This change fixes the bug by removing the second definition of
InvalidContentType class and leaving only one which works correctly
with all code. Also adds unit tests for exceptions to prevent this and similar bugs.

Change-Id: I5d932d75ad184a0a6c6419190f2940bd47b7504e
Fixes: bug #1104090

commit_message:
update whitebox testing for deleted type change

the deleted column has now changed in nature, and is now
an int and not a boolean. Postgresql cares about this difference.
Update tests to be runnable on postgresql.

Change-Id: I208db9d5948deabcc8e8cd983a9b39ddd0653101

TEMPEST_CONFIG_DIR TEMPEST_CONFIG was in this file in the past, this can be readed.

- run_tests.sh MUST not have permanent side effect.
- An environment variable SHOULD NOT override a configured value.

I would prefer the ENVIRONMENT variable solution (TEMPEST_USE_XML), since it just a SHOULD NOT. 

This env var usage, must be documented in the etc/temest.conf.sample as well.

I think both xml/json should be default ON.

It is possible to leave on option empty in a config file. in this case the env var can take precedence.

I am open for any other solution, but I would like to avoid config file edition by the run_tests.sh

If the default both is ON, we even able to remove this option from the configuration file."}, {'account_id': 5196, 'date': '2013-01-25 15:05:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Abandoned

Based on discussions in the ML and on IRC we are not going to split XML and JSON testing right now. I'll reopen and reinvestigate if this changes in the future."}]

commit_message:
Add run_tests.sh support for separate xml and json

This adds support for enabling xml testing in run tests. It
adds 2 options to run_tests. -x/--xml to use xml testing, and
-b/--both to run both xml and json in series. This has the
caveat that projects which do not use xml will have their tests
run twice. (For example glance)

Implements bp split-xml-json-tests

Change-Id: Ie75d29d045ce5c4ff7aa1854128393e74d816224

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-25 13:07:09.000000000', 'message': 'Fix broken XML in UCS driver for Cisco plugin

UCS driver in Cisco plugin contains XML templates - python strings
each of which is used to form a body of specific "Cisco UCS Manager
XML API" request. The actual XML in these strings containes a lot of
errors: missing spaces between attributes, lots of tags without
enclosing symbol '>', etc. The corresponding unit test failes.

This patch fixes desribed errors together with one similar error
in test itself and make unit tests for driver pass again.

Change-Id: I752308fbe6429d8c89142d795ba3816b0770803e
Fixes: bug #1101944
'}]
commit_message:
Fix broken XML in UCS driver for Cisco plugin

UCS driver in Cisco plugin contains XML templates - python strings
each of which is used to form a body of specific "Cisco UCS Manager
XML API" request. The actual XML in these strings containes a lot of
errors: missing spaces between attributes, lots of tags without
enclosing symbol '>', etc. The corresponding unit test failes.

This patch fixes desribed errors together with one similar error
in test itself and make unit tests for driver pass again.

Change-Id: I752308fbe6429d8c89142d795ba3816b0770803e
Fixes: bug #1101944

commit_message:
heat engine : AutoScalingGroup implement Cooldown property

AutoScalingGroup schema accepts Cooldown but it doesn't do anything
so implement Cooldown in a similar way to Scaling Policy

fixes bug 1097850

Change-Id: I0dae79fad5c13b0ae588b1a2ea4fe67eb06e3746
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

idempotent. This means multiple concurrent messages will not leave

commit_message:
Eliminate race conditions in floating association

This makes associating and disassociating floating ips atomic and
idempotent. This means multiple concurrent messages will not leave
behind iptables rules and concurrent request will not cause odd
failures.

Fixes bug 1092762 and bug 1092761.

Change-Id: Idbcad6c1d2a3d4881cf7180b848ed3844fac4054
(cherry picked from commit 881a93473c32a7c7e23a8e6dcede8394053408c6)

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-22 15:59:55.000000000', 'message': "Avoid stuck task_state on snapshot image failure

Fixes bug LP 1101136

Previously if the glance interaction failed prior to an
instance being snapshot'd or backed up, the task state
remained stuck at image_snapshot/backup.

The normal task state reversion logic did not kick in,
as this is limited to the compute layer, whereas the
intial glance interaction occurs within the API layer.

Now, we avoid this problem by delaying setting the task
state until the initial initial image creation/retrieval
has completed.

Change-Id: Id498ae6b3674306743013e4fe99837da8e2031b5
"}]
commit_message:
Avoid stuck task_state on snapshot image failure

Fixes bug LP 1101136

Previously if the glance interaction failed prior to an
instance being snapshot'd or backed up, the task state
remained stuck at image_snapshot/backup.

The normal task state reversion logic did not kick in,
as this is limited to the compute layer, whereas the
intial glance interaction occurs within the API layer.

Now, we avoid this problem by delaying setting the task
state until the initial initial image creation/retrieval
has completed.

Change-Id: Id498ae6b3674306743013e4fe99837da8e2031b5

commit_message:
Test Case to check "swift object expiry"

Adds object expiry test case to "test_object_expiry.py" so as to
validate the object expiry support by trying to GET object after
expiry time.

Implements: blueprint add-swift-object-expiry-test
Change-Id: I1a29e8ae57e9f8661c21000775153bda78b0c689

commit_message:
crazy

Do not merge! This change is not for merge!

It is for performance testing on full tempest run, with different
image and flavor. Not the tempest is the right location for these
changes anyway.

* 1 MB RAM
* 0.5 MB disk
* frozen VM

Do not merge!

Change-Id: I6ab8702d88b7057b9179095f1a23b1f39cf5361a

commit_message:
heat engine : ScalingPolicy implement Cooldown property

Implement the Cooldown property, which the schema currently
marks as implemented, but it doesn't actually do anything

ref bug 1097850

Change-Id: I0cb1b24baa4377be4a78b2a7b92fb1ed5371fb6f
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

heat tests : autoscaling test add missing VerifyAll

Add logic to verify stubbed calls to loadbalancer reload,
also break up the tests a bit into functionally related
chunks instead of having two mega-tests

commit_message:
Enable 'ec2-user' in HEAT for quantal images.

Employs some workarounds that can be removed when bugs reference in
comments are fixed elsewhere.

Change-Id: If423844f0dfabbddd4d0d7b8ad8fcf6d32693195

The PAE flag only makes sense on the i686 architecture, so we shouldn't be setting it for other architectures."}, {'account_id': 2069, 'date': '2013-01-17 11:59:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi Daniel,

Win7 guest would fail on booting unless I set pae flag in libvirt xml. In current situation, such guests cannot work in nova. Do you have any suggestion for this? Is it better to refactor the patch to set the pae for guest according to arch(i386/x86_64)?

Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-01-17 12:01:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Yes, as I just said, we should only set it for i686 arch'}, {'account_id': 2069, 'date': '2013-01-17 13:00:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-01-17 13:07:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

You also need to update the test_libvirt.py test suite to verify that PAE is being set correctly, and ensure the test suite does the right thing when run on both i686 and x86_64 hosts"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-01-17 13:34:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Bug 1100697

Change-Id: I12dc2ae7acfe8fdfd25d46976088b25c90c37cf9
"}, {'created': '2013-01-17 13:00:20.000000000', 'message': "libvirt: enable pae flag for KVM and Xen guest.

Bug 1100697

Currently, nova doesn't enable pae setting for Xen and KVM guest
in its libvirt driver. Windows( Win7 in my environment ) guests
would not boot successful in such case. This patch adds pae setting
in libvirt driver for i686 Xen and KVM guest, which would fix this
problem.

Change-Id: I12dc2ae7acfe8fdfd25d46976088b25c90c37cf9
"}]
commit_message:
libvirt: enable pae flag for KVM and Xen guest.

Bug 1100697

Currently, nova doesn't enable pae setting for Xen and KVM guest
in its libvirt driver. Windows( Win7 in my environment ) guests
would not boot successful in such case. This patch adds pae setting
in libvirt driver for i686 Xen and KVM guest, which would fix this
problem.

Change-Id: I12dc2ae7acfe8fdfd25d46976088b25c90c37cf9

commit_message:
Use instance itself to attach volumes in BareMetalDriver.spawn()

Now we should pass to attach_volume() an instance instead of
instance['name'] as a parameter.

blueprint general-bare-metal-provisioning-framework

Change-Id: I7771f7524329832077867f4998f1970829bfa362

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-24 23:13:00.000000000', 'message': 'Naming unique hostname when booting multi instances.

This patch adds a param "nameTemplate" for booting multi
instance at a time. The hostname can be named by a template
which supports launch_id and image_name for example use
--nameTemplate "%-(launch_id)d" will naming as myinstance-1.

basically implement blueprint multi-boot-instance-naming
DocImpact
Change-Id: I691140a52adb0847624ecf360a8499acb9772127
'}]
commit_message:
Naming unique hostname when booting multi instances.

This patch adds a param "nameTemplate" for booting multi
instance at a time. The hostname can be named by a template
which supports launch_id and image_name for example use
--nameTemplate "%-(launch_id)d" will naming as myinstance-1.

basically implement blueprint multi-boot-instance-naming
DocImpact
Change-Id: I691140a52adb0847624ecf360a8499acb9772127

commit_message:
Fix hosts extension and enable its tests

This patch corrects the import in hosts.py, fix the DB API
service_get_by_host_and_topic raises ServiceNotFound exception with
right parameter and move tests to the right place so that they are
enabled.

Fix LP bug: #1104231

Change-Id: I07c486f456196a3812eb5274b950ab9560a51cf3

commit_message:
Support for SSL in wsgi.Server

SSL are entirely optional. Support for SSL as well using code from glance. We
have some new options for configuring the SSL support. There are tests for
accessing a sample app w/o ipv6 or ssl, one with just ssl and one with
ipv6 and ssl

Fixes LP# 1101342

DocImpact

Change-Id: I68ae6354595fa962f168489634604d66d4653cfc

commit_message:
Fix double reboot issue during soft reboot

Using the ID of domain in Libvirt to recognize the hard reboot has been
implemented or not, if the ID changed, we believe the domain has been rebooted,
return True and break from soft reboot.

Fixes: bug #1046356

Change-Id: Iec2f9e8225cfe2779f84d2095667f3c0e621e935

Since I was involved in the code originally I was curious what changed, but I'm confused about the necessity of this change..."}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-01-25 03:45:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Two things:

Firstly, the sense of the error was inverted (it claimed No os processes, but actually there are some) for casual readers.

Secondly the log message and the exception are separated by an arbitrary amount of teardown and cleanup code. So this is just clearer for folk that read the exception - they can see the list immediately rather than scanning up to find it.

Obviously this makes no different to the actual root cause of the test failures.'}]

Shouldn't this code go under cinder/volume/drivers/san/emc ?"}, {'account_id': 5997, 'date': '2013-01-19 01:19:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

'}, {'account_id': 5997, 'date': '2013-01-19 01:19:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Shouldn't this code go under cinder/volume/drivers/san/emc ?"}, {'account_id': 6491, 'date': '2013-01-19 04:45:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

If we are only having iscsi and FC drivers, cinder/volume/drivers/san/emc seems to be the right place, but we are also thinking about adding nfs support down the road (may be the F release).  So we'd like to put all EMC drivers under the same EMC folder."}, {'account_id': 6491, 'date': '2013-01-19 12:45:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Sorry, it should be "H release" instead of "F release".'}, {'account_id': 5997, 'date': '2013-01-19 16:36:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I think it's a good idea to put them all under an 'emc' folder.  I just thought it made more sense to put the 'emc' folder under the 'san' folder."}, {'account_id': 170, 'date': '2013-01-19 21:22:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

Found a missing an import.

Xing thanks for the contribution. After looking at the common code, it seems like a great deal of this can be refactored further. Not in this commit of course, but there are 10 instances for example where a connection is established with _get_ecom_connection and it's checked if there is a connection was actually established, if not log, raise. This is also the same with things like _get_storage_type() and _find_pool()."}, {'account_id': 6491, 'date': '2013-01-20 04:11:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 6491, 'date': '2013-01-20 04:29:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

Walter, thanks for the comments.  I agree that putting  emc_iscsi.py and emc_fc.py under san/emc makes sense.  My concern is that if we put emc_nfs.py under san/emc, it seems to be out of place.

Mike, thanks for catching the missing import.  I added that.  Regarding your comments about further refactoring, I'm thinking I can call get_ecom_connection() in __init__() and make connection a member variable.  We just need to remind user to restart cinder-volume if ECOM server is restarted.  Regarding the storage_type and pool, that information is more dynamic.  The storage_type here is really a pool name.  User should be able to change it without restarting cinder-volume service.  So I'll keep storage_type and find_pool unchanged.  I'll make those changes in my next patch."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-01-20 04:41:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

commit_message:
Update EMC SMI-S iSCSI Driver

Refactor EMC SMI-S based iSCSI driver.  There are lots of common code
that can be shared between iSCSI and FC drivers using SMI-S.  Break
the original emc.py into two files: emc_smis_common.py and
emc_smis_iscsi.py.  Also added support for get_volume_stats() and
create_cloned_volume().  get_volume_stats() will be revisited after
winston-d's changes.  copy volume<->image will be revisited after
avishay-il's changes.

Change-Id: I90dc3599ec2fd5bb86a3e988111a8aee5de7efea

commit_message:
A native Swift container resource type.

Implements blueprint swift-resource-type

The properties schema maps to the swift headers
that are set during container creation.

The schema allows any arbitrary X-Container-Meta-* header to
be set in the template, which will be useful for users who
store arbitrary header keys.

This will be used during the presentation demo at LCA
next week.

Change-Id: I35e594cbe3cc251d5b48b41ea78ed2edda8aa807

commit_message:
Make a dedicated InstanceGroup

Make it the basis of the autoscaling group, the
main difference is you change the number of instances
via update (manually) or not at all.

This can be achieved using the autoscaling group, but
this is clearer from the user's perspective.

Implements blueprint static-inst-group

commit_message:
populate dnsmasq lease db with valid leases

At start dnsmasq retrieves its lease db by calling the nova-dhcpbridge
script with the init action.

Previously we were returning all allocated IPs in the network and
calculating the lease exirpation time based upon instances.updated_at
or instances.created_at.

Now we are only returning entries for IPs that are allocated and leased.
Additionally we set the lease expiration time to be i
now + CONF.dhcp_lease_time

Change-Id: I66764666b96336cefa7d0fed3111859de3a5e9bc
Fixes: bug #1103260

[{'created': '2013-01-21 15:45:51.000000000', 'message': "Make v2 image tags test not load system policy

Since commit 74a8601, I'm seeing this test attempting to load
/etc/glance/policy.conf.

Switch to using IsolatedUnitTest which copies the policy into a
temp dir.

Change-Id: Ibd84ed753de5abf91ee597918ba56130ddd0550e
"}]
commit_message:
Make v2 image tags test not load system policy

Since commit 74a8601, I'm seeing this test attempting to load
/etc/glance/policy.conf.

Switch to using IsolatedUnitTest which copies the policy into a
temp dir.

Change-Id: Ibd84ed753de5abf91ee597918ba56130ddd0550e

The default for the verbose config option is False and the sample config
file should reflect that.

Also, comment out the defaults of the config options so that it is clear
that the sample file is showing the default in the code rather than
overriding it.

Change-Id: I3913ea54465658d93dc56e014dfe5d911b0541d6
'}]
commit_message:
Update glance config files with log defaults

The default for the verbose config option is False and the sample config
file should reflect that.

Also, comment out the defaults of the config options so that it is clear
that the sample file is showing the default in the code rather than
overriding it.

Change-Id: I3913ea54465658d93dc56e014dfe5d911b0541d6

Don't log at all if debugging is not turned on

Else the http module prints this out on each command - yuk

commit_message:
Refactored run_command for better naming

This distinguishes this difference between
running commands on the local compute node and
the remote system, the VIOS.

bp powervm-compute-resize-migration

Change-Id: I57967e291f52d2745cd7d6d53553e37d9de07a6b

Minor questions, but looks good.'}, {'account_id': 3189, 'date': '2013-01-24 16:08:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Andrew Laski,

I could add some logging around the host name and pass it, but we don't do anything with the hostname in any of the functions we use. In fact most of the nova code in general ignores the hostname/display_name/display_description fields in favor of UUIDs or instance IDs. I'm somewhat dis-inclined to log and pass around a value we don't typical use for anything."}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-01-24 16:18:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

That's fair.  Maybe it would be good to add a note above the argument explaining that it's being grabbed to prevent an error, but is not needed. commit_message:
Support optional 4 arg for nova-dhcpbridge

dnsmasq will call the add, old, and del actions with an optional
4 argument of hostname if the hostname is known. Since we populate
the hostname in the DHCP host file its always passed to us.

Add an optional 4 argument for hostname for the add, old, and del
actions.

Change-Id: I1a6c095324be2424d6c1d469877b254f88fba4aa
Fixes: bug #1103783

[{'created': '2013-01-23 04:21:26.000000000', 'message': 'Get updated vol status in volume.api.reserve.

A race condtion was discovered where a nova volume attach
could easily be performed twice for the same volume.  Although
the cinder attach update would fail, this occured after the BDM
updates were made and in essence the attach to the compute instance
had already been issued.

This change simply forces a get from the DB of the volume-ref in the
reserve call and checks if an attach is already in progress.

Fixes bug: 1096983

Change-Id: Ie0e4156d691ee92b6981078ef0ba62f8c4cdf0c8
'}]
commit_message:
Get updated vol status in volume.api.reserve.

A race condtion was discovered where a nova volume attach
could easily be performed twice for the same volume.  Although
the cinder attach update would fail, this occured after the BDM
updates were made and in essence the attach to the compute instance
had already been issued.

This change simply forces a get from the DB of the volume-ref in the
reserve call and checks if an attach is already in progress.

Fixes bug: 1096983

Change-Id: Ie0e4156d691ee92b6981078ef0ba62f8c4cdf0c8

subject: Increase maximum URI size for EC2 API to 16k

The tools we're using (HTCondor -- http://research.cs.wisc.edu/htcondor/) -- uses libcurl and HTTP GET.  My guess is that many other tools do too (maybe even the AWS CLI).  I'll check with the Condor folks on changing to POST, but I still think this patch is a good idea."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-01-21 21:30:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

limit seems enormous'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2013-01-22 02:32:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Just fyi, when urls and such start to get over 2k characters, typically you switch to using POST for fields instead of using GET params. This is due to browsers and other tools not typically supporting more than 2k.

See: http://support.microsoft.com/kb/208427'}, {'account_id': 5174, 'date': '2013-01-22 22:43:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2013-01-23 01:52:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-01-23 12:25:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I feel like I need a better justification on this one, what kind of GET strings are getting sent that are bigger than 8k?"}, {'account_id': 6661, 'date': '2013-01-23 13:30:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

In our particular use case, it's an X.509 proxy with extensions that we us for authentication, encryption, and integrity checking.  With the 8k limit we were unable to instantiate images at the OpenStack installation at Rutherford Appleton Laboratory in order to do High Energy Physics research, and we'll see similar limitations at the OpenStack deployments at CERN.  I imagine there are plenty other use cases that may want more than 8k of image-specific contextualization data and most if not all of the tools out there use HTTP GET."}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2013-01-23 16:52:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I'm alright with this. Alternate punchline: would chunked transfer encoding be appropriate here?"}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-01-23 18:56:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

The problem I have with this is that Apache has an 8k url limit, so this change will drastically limit our future options to have something other than eventlet handle our requests.

I would much rather fix the APIs that are trying to jam this down as a GET string (which still confuses me as to what query needs that much data in the query parameters for a read only request).

If a custom extension is using GET to push data to the server, that's just wrong anyway."}, {'account_id': 6661, 'date': '2013-01-23 20:39:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Sean's point seems reasonable. Apache supports changing the length via limitrequestline, but I think you need to recompile from the default.  Most of the third party tools either use HTTP GET exclusively or gloss over the use of POST for the API calls instantiating images -- HTCondor, EC2/AWS native tools, even Boto has GET as the default verb. 

As an interim step, would you accept this patch if I changed the default from 64k back down to 8k?  That would still give admins some flexibility until the clients switch to POST."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-01-23 23:55:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

At minimum the default should go back to whatever it was before, so lets get that patch in there.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2013-01-24 00:06:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Do not merge

Can you explain what command is sending this incredibly long url?  I am not seeing where we accept userdata via a get param.'}, {'account_id': 6661, 'date': '2013-01-24 01:18:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Hi Vish, 

The large URI is from encoding a large user-data blob.

The EC2 API specifies that one can use either GET or POST:
http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/using-query-api.html

Note that all the EC2 examples given use GET (so it's not surprising that many client tools do, too).  The client tools succeed on EC2 and Nimbus (http://bugzilla.mcs.anl.gov/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=6992) but not nova.  

As far as I can tell from the nova code, it doesn't discriminate GET or POST but just parses the request and renders a response. Given that the API explicitly says either GET or POST is acceptable, I think that keeping the default at 8k and letting the admin configure it as needed is reasonable.

I'll resubmit this patch with the 8k default."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-01-24 01:50:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

That's kind of crazy. I never realized how insane the EC2 API was.

It would be nice if we only had to bump this for the EC2 API, and not the others."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2013-01-24 01:55:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: No score

That sounds good.'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-01-24 02:39:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Burt, can you come up with a way to only have to adjust this for EC2 API? At that point we should just set EC2 to 16k (that's what you said it supports?), and not make this a config option."}, {'account_id': 6661, 'date': '2013-01-24 06:01:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

AWS is limited to 16k, but that's mentioned in the User's Guide, not the API, so you could interpret that as an implementation detail -- but I'll go ahead and make the changes.  Sadly this will make the patch significantly larger."}, {'account_id': 6661, 'date': '2013-01-24 06:41:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2013-01-24 06:58:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

the ec2 api is also run from nova-api if it is in enabled apis so i think you need to change it there as well."}, {'account_id': 6661, 'date': '2013-01-24 07:09:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-01-24 07:30:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Doesn't seem to work

[{'created': '2013-01-16 19:19:16.000000000', 'message': 'Make URL length limit configurable for wsgi

We have an application where user data is sometimes (much) bigger
than 8192 bytes (AWS allows at least 16k).  This makes it user-configurable
and sets the default to 64k.

Fixes bug 1098646

than 8192 bytes (AWS allows at least 16k).  This makes it user-configurable
and sets the default to 64k.

Unit test added.

Fixes bug 1098646

commit_message:
Increase maximum URI size for EC2 API to 16k

The EC2 API supports both HTTP GET and POST agnostically.  It also supports
user-data of 16k -- meaning that client tools could generate 16k URIs.
The WSGI default limit is 8k; this raises it.

Fixes bug 1098646.

Change-Id: Idec460d88b2affab970c9d9f39fa61295db035c5

commit_message:
Remove useless code

- There's no need to call parent init function since that's the default
  behaviour.
- The token attribute is nor used nor updated anywhere.

Change-Id: Ib0b2729a396a2d761931ce0e178c49c49814eb21
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

commit_message:
Restore Python 2.6 compatibility

Python 2.6 did not have a keyword argument 'output'
in the constructor defined yet, which caused a TypeError
exception

Change-Id: I4d455bef3480a7511172c58fd4794fa1e8acce8c

The requests library supports timeout that's a floating point and not just integers. Seems like it would be easy to for the cli and api to support floating point for timeout rather than just integers.

Another question, the note on the requests documentation indicates that the timeout option only effects[sic] the connection process, so if keystone takes a long time to process the response it doesn't actually timeout... is that how we want --timeout to work?"}, {'account_id': 6486, 'date': '2013-01-16 19:11:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I tried out the change and it actually does timeout when the request takes a long time, so it's not just on the connect as the request documentation says, so I take back that part of my previous comment. I still think we should support timeout as a float since request supports it."}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2013-01-16 19:17:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Float makes sense to me.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-01-16 23:35:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

i'd support a change to float, whether it's done in this patch or not (doing it later would be backwards-compatible with this)"}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2013-01-17 01:56:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-01-17 02:20:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Allow request timeout to be specified.

Add a new cli argument (--timeout) which
is by default 600 seconds which will be
set in the requests library so that timeouts
can occur correctly.

Change-Id: I845c55dfb6f6b8345663ccdb5b150a2655f20026

commit_message:
Add support for enabling XML testing in tempest.

Change I139dac23194b3abdf26a0d3622461942478facb5 splits up
the XML and JSON testing in tempest. So each will need to
be run individually.

Change-Id: I10557a9082e01f377bb160a2c6463986f744a347

commit_message:
Log exception details.

When there is an error while initializing the backing store,
log entrires are now displaying more details specifying
the reason of failure.

Also instead of normal info message, log entries display
warnings in this case.

Fixes: bug #1103073
Change-Id: Icb7cc3c27325cfb0e4d62f466d28ecf9995d91ac

commit_message:
Fixes and Improves Guest Agent Image

    Fixes assignment of tmp file when creating sudoers file
    Moved libmysqlclient18 to mysql element (for future compat)
    Disable AppArmor profile for mysqld so cnf file can be changed

Change-Id: I88fcceaf423237b4cf59c111b047453cd389f9b3
Fixes: bug #1103876

[{'created': '2013-01-22 21:05:43.000000000', 'message': 'Fix double reboot during resume_state_on_host_boot

Re-basing my commit introduced a mistake I did not catch before the
merge occurred.  resume_state_on_host_boot is calling both
_create_domain_and_network followed by _hard_reboot. It should only
call _hard_reboot.

Change-Id: I52be2c0d0c85abe6386842c980f26b3c5713e3e3
'}, {'created': '2013-01-22 22:57:04.000000000', 'message': 'Fix double reboot during resume_state_on_host_boot

Re-basing my commit introduced a mistake I did not catch before the
merge occurred.  resume_state_on_host_boot is calling both
_create_domain_and_network followed by _hard_reboot. It should only
call _hard_reboot.

Change-Id: I52be2c0d0c85abe6386842c980f26b3c5713e3e3
'}]
commit_message:
Fix double reboot during resume_state_on_host_boot

Re-basing my commit introduced a mistake I did not catch before the
merge occurred.  resume_state_on_host_boot is calling both
_create_domain_and_network followed by _hard_reboot. It should only
call _hard_reboot.

Change-Id: I52be2c0d0c85abe6386842c980f26b3c5713e3e3

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-21 16:58:55.000000000', 'message': 'Sync latest cfg and log from oslo-incubator

Changes include:

  c5984ba Move logging config options into the log module
  751c35b Verbose should not enable debug level logging
  edcdd25 Improve millisecond logging
  a8973c5 Revert "Support lookup of value using "group.key""

The most significant of these changes is defaulting to the WARNING log
level which was discussed on openstack-dev:

  http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-January/004223.html

This is behaviour already documented in doc/source/configuring.rst at
least.

Fixes bug #989269

DocImpact

Change-Id: I8ed9107193a811f50ecfd9b34e99e933774405ab
'}]
commit_message:
Sync latest cfg and log from oslo-incubator

Changes include:

  c5984ba Move logging config options into the log module
  751c35b Verbose should not enable debug level logging
  edcdd25 Improve millisecond logging
  a8973c5 Revert "Support lookup of value using "group.key""

The most significant of these changes is defaulting to the WARNING log
level which was discussed on openstack-dev:

  http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-January/004223.html

This is behaviour already documented in doc/source/configuring.rst at
least.

Fixes bug #989269

DocImpact

Change-Id: I8ed9107193a811f50ecfd9b34e99e933774405ab

Looking good, but a few thoughts so far:

1.  For bulk deletes, API sticklers would probably prefer the body to be wrapped in JSON or XML.  Possibly something similar to how S3 does it: http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AmazonS3/latest/API/multiobjectdeleteapi.html

2.  We should probably check the size of each file in the archive to shortcut files that are larget that max object size.

3.  The return data should also return XML for clients that are requesting XML responses."}, {'account_id': 995, 'date': '2013-01-09 21:01:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-01-09 21:30:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Works for me

Bulk Requests: auto extract archive and bulk delete middleware.

Fix small problem in ratelimiting middleware.

DocImpact

Change-Id: Ide3e0b9f4887626c30cae0b97eb7e2237b1df3ed

commit_message:
Updated image loop to not use an enumerator

*  We are not using the enumerator in the loop. So this has been rewritten to not use it.

Change-Id: I18cab2556190e8ce5c202c5f5e7b8e6b3dfe8f59

commit_message:
Make failures in the periodic tests more detailed.

The current tests are very opaque when something fails. This change makes the
failure easier to understand without a debugger. The testtools version is
bumped to get a new HasLength matcher.

Change-Id: Iceafa70f88a8cc31a1b0ba912fe32a9fef1b2f18

commit_message:
Cisco plugin cleanup

Removing unused plugins and code from the Cisco plugin framework.

Change-Id: Ib22d173a088ad50b410a51a1d92685259d0af473
Implements: blueprint cisco-plugin-cleanup
